Most Recent Updates

[DRAFT] Moai is Great Haxe May be Better

January 16, 2013 >> I've been talking a lot about how good Moai is, even compared to the quirky but successful Unity3D game engine. Moai is billed as a game engine for professional developers and that sums it up pretty well. It's designed by people who make games and are good programmers. It's a pleasure to use and the use of Lua makes prototyping fast. Moai is a great cross-platform game engine, but ulimately I think it's not cross-platform enough. This isn't an implementation problem since it was always meant to focus on the two main mobile platforms. A couple years ago that may... read more >>

[DRAFT] Multiplayer Games with PubNub

January 3, 2013 >> As mentioned in an earlier post, mid-year I switched RapidFire to Moai (from Unity) for a variety of reasons. Moai is a mobile cross-platform game engine released by Zipline Games. It's open source, free to use (under a CPAL license) and well designed. It's been a pleasure to work with and looking back I think it was definitely a good move for RapidFire. Recently I put together an API for Moai for PubNub in order to use it for multiplayer. If you're not familiar with it, PubNub is a fast and reliable publish/subscribe service that allows for quasi-P2P communication using JSON.... read more >>

New Development Article in GameCareerGuide

June 29, 2012 >> An article we’ve been working on for GameCareerGuide (a sister publication to Gamasutra) is now live. The article covers using Unity (we wrote it back when we were still using Unity full time) to make a simple infinite-scrolling space game. Here’s the link: Making An Infinite-Scrolling 2D Game With Unity and Boo read more >>

Why We are Killing Our Game and Moving from Unity to Moai

June 26, 2012 >> We’re killing our current game after six months of development time. We’re also starting a new game. In the transition we’re changing most of the processes that we’ve put in place including moving from Unity3D to Moai. One of the hardest decisions you face as an entrepreneur is knowing when to kill a project (or to dump a bad client or to kill a business entirely). To do difficult things it’s critical to have a “never die” attitude. But it’s also critical to know when to cut losses and move on. If you’re a student of entrepreneurialism, you’ve probably heard people... read more >>

Untitled Game Mega Screenshot Update

June 21, 2012 >> I haven’t put out any information about our upcoming game since we finalized the (new, updated) concept. We’re in heavy development now and are still planning on having this game in testing by the end of the month. The following screenshots outline a lot of the basic gameplay. Combat is getting finalized now, so there are only a few shots of combat available. Most importantly, combat will include physics-engine driven homing missiles, flare countermeasures and other interesting bits flying around the screen. What is this game? To save a dying civilization, you have to cross the known galaxy. I want to call it a... read more >>

A RapidFire Blog

This blog consists of updates about this company as well as select information about the game industry and gaming.

It's company policy to publish [DRAFTS] of posts that are felt to be informative but not yet in a final state.

Posts are written by RapidFire's founder, Matthew Smith, unless otherwise noted.

You're welcome to contact him: matthew@rapidfirestudio.com

This blog was built using Jekyll and hosted on GitHub Pages. You can learn more and even fork and modify this blog at its public repository.
